title: Larry Gowell
text:
Lawrence Clyde Gowell (May 2, 1948 – May 11, 2020) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="baseball%20player">player</a>. He was a right-handed <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> who played in two <a href="games%20pitched">games</a> for the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a> of <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> in . Gowell was drafted by the Yankees in the fourth round of the <a href="1967%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20draft">1967 Major League Baseball draft</a> on June 6, 1967. After <a href="win%20%28baseball%29">winning</a> every game at <a href="Edward%20Little%20High%20School">Edward Little High School</a> in <a href="Auburn%2C%20Maine">Auburn, Maine</a>, he was signed by the Yankees to a professional contract. He pitched in the <a href="Minor%20League%20Baseball">minor leagues</a> for six years before making his major league debut, after winning 11 games in a row in Double-A. Gowell was listed at tall and .
Major league career.
The Yankees called up Gowell from their minor league organization in 1972 to play as a September call-up. Gowell made his major league debut on September 21 against the <a href="Milwaukee%20Brewers">Milwaukee Brewers</a>. The game was held at <a href="County%20Stadium">County Stadium</a>, with 4,185 people attending the game. After <a href="Rusty%20Torres">Rusty Torres</a> <a href="pinch%20hitter">pinch hit</a> for <a href="Fred%20Beene">Fred Beene</a> in the sixth inning, Gowell came in to replace Beene on the mound in the bottom of the sixth. He pitched two innings with one <a href="strikeout">strikeout</a> before <a href="Felipe%20Alou">Felipe Alou</a> was called on to pinch-hit for him in the top of the eighth inning. The Yankees lost the game 6-4. On October 4, as a starting pitcher (again facing Milwaukee) Gowell hit a <a href="double%20%28baseball%29">double</a> on a 3–2 count, hitting a <a href="fastball">fastball</a> by pitcher <a href="Jim%20Lonborg">Jim Lonborg</a> for his first and only Major League <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hit</a> and the last hit by a pitcher in a regular season <a href="American%20League">American League</a> game before the start of the <a href="designated%20hitter">designated hitter</a> rule. The baseball that Gowell hit now resides in the <a href="National%20Baseball%20Hall%20of%20Fame%20and%20Museum">National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum</a>, in <a href="Cooperstown%2C%20New%20York">Cooperstown, New York</a>. Although Gowell allowed only one run during that game, the Yankees lost 1–0. It was Gowell's only MLB <a href="decision%20%28baseball%29">decision</a>.
Death.
Gowell died while playing golf on May 11, 2020, aged 72.
